RCVAccession.Title: NM_000251.3(MSH2):c.860dup (p.Gln288fs) AND Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal neoplasms

GermlineClassification.ReviewStatus: criteria provided, multiple submitters, no conflicts
criteria provided, multiple submitters, no conflicts

AttributeSet.Attribute: Lynch syndrome is characterized by an increased risk for colorectal cancer (CRC) and cancers of the endometrium, ovary, stomach, small bowel, urinary tract, biliary tract, brain (usually glioblastoma), skin (sebaceous adenomas, sebaceous carcinomas, and keratoacanthomas), pancreas, and prostate. Cancer risks and age of onset vary depending on the associated gene. Several other cancer types have been reported to occur in individuals with Lynch syndrome (e.g., breast, sarcomas, adrenocortical carcinoma). However, the data are not sufficient to demonstrate that the risk of developing these cancers is increased in individuals with Lynch syndrome.

Citation.CitationText: Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) Clinical Practice Statement: Screening for Lynch Syndrome in Endometrial Cancer
NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology (NCCN Guidelines®) Colon Cancer, 2024

Citation.Abbrev: NCI PDQ, Genetics of Colorectal Cancer
NCI PDQ, Breast and Gynecologic Cancers

Citation.CitationText: American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics Family History ACT Sheet, Colon Cancer (Asymptomatic), 2012

American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics, Genomic Testing (Secondary Findings) ACT Sheet, MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, EPCAM Pathogenic Variants, Lynch Syndrome (Hereditary Non-polyposis Colon Cancer [HNPCC]), 2019
UK NICE Guideline NG151, Colorectal cancer, 2021
UK NICE Diagnostics Guidance DG42, Testing strategies for Lynch syndrome in people with endometrial cancer, 2020

Cancer risks and age of onset vary depending on the associated gene. ClinVarSubmissionID.title: MSH2:c.860dupG and Hereditary non-polyposis colon cancer

ClinVarAccession.SubmitterName: Women's Health and Genetics/Laboratory Corporation of America, LabCorp

Classification.Comment: Converted during submission to Likely pathogenic.
This variant is considered pathogenic. This variant creates a frameshift predicted to result in premature protein truncation.

AttributeSet.Attribute: Myriad Autosomal Dominant, Autosomal Recessive and X-Linked Classification Criteria (2023)

Classification.Comment: This sequence change creates a premature translational stop signal (p.Gln288Thrfs*3) in the MSH2 gene. It is expected to result in an absent or disrupted protein product. Loss-of-function variants in MSH2 are known to be pathogenic (PMID: 15849733, 24362816). This variant is not present in population databases (gnomAD no frequency). This premature translational stop signal has been observed in individual(s) with Lynch syndrome (PMID: 26248088). ClinVar contains an entry for this variant (Variation ID: 36579). For these reasons, this variant has been classified as Pathogenic.

The c.860dupG pathogenic mutation, located in coding exon 5 of the MSH2 gene, results from a duplication of G at nucleotide position 860, causing a translational frameshift with a predicted alternate stop codon (p.Q288Tfs*3). This alteration has been reported in multiple individuals with a personal and/or family history of cancers associated with Lynch syndrome (Guindalini RS et al. Gastroenterology. 2015 Nov;149:1446-53; Espenschied CR et al. J. Clin. Oncol. 2017 Aug;35(22):2568-2575). In addition to the clinical data presented in the literature, this alteration is expected to result in loss of function by premature protein truncation or nonsense-mediated mRNA decay. As such, this alteration is interpreted as a disease-causing mutation.
